ECM3, ECM3 General
18.2 ECM3 General
� General Information
The basic concept is based on the recommendations of the VDA (as expressed in the written documentation
of the VDA ETC working group "Arbeitskreis EGAS"). The monitoring concept for electronic control units (ECUs)
uses three levels; this document provides a more detailed description of the processor monitoring level (level
3 in VDA terms).
The current document describes the monitoring concept for the main processor (level3 monitoring).
It should be noted that the goal of the level3 monitoring is to detect errors within the regular processing of the
data and transit the vehicle in case of detection of errors into a safe state by a so called ?fault reaction?.
The fault reaction as such is to disable power stages for the actuators driving thecontrolled devices (e.g.
throttle, injectors etc.); thus stopping the vehicle and preventing reactions like e.g. undesired acceleration.
It has to be noted that the disabling of these power stages is done only within the ECU to ensure the safety
integrity of the ECU itself. In case of power stages remote controlled, the ECU provides only a mechanism for
the transition to a safe state of the linked actuators (e.g. interruption of communication)
The fact that (up to a certain maximal number) a reset is triggered after this disabling is only done in order
to increase the availability of the car (i.e., to potentially enable the driver to continue his driving relatively
undisturbed without having to use the ignition key)!
Based on the VDA guidelines, the processor monitoring level consists of at least two separate hardware com-
ponents: the main controller (MC) and the monitoring unit (MU). The former is generally realized by a micro
controller (�C), while the latter might just as well be realized by an application-speci?c integrated circuit (ASIC),
i.e., some speci?cally designed piece of hardware; this MU is almost exclusively used for processor monitoring
functionality.
In order to be able to detect an error within the regular processing, the MU provides an independent (hard-
ware) instance which can judge (as far as it is safety-relevant) whether the behavior of the MC is appropriate
according to actual environment conditions and demands (like the driver?s wish expressed, e.g., in terms of
pushing the accelerator pedal); the behavior of the MU, in turn, is then monitored by the MC in order to ascer-
tain that the MU is still able to perform its monitoring duties.
A schematic overview of the system is presented in the following ?gure ?Figure 1 Sketch of processor mon-
itoring with two power stages? including the required disable lines from the MC and the MU to the power
stages; note that this picture does not include the redundant analogue input signal based on which the A/D
conversion on the MU is performed and then sent to the MC in order to determine proper functioning of the
A/D converter on the MC (by comparing the conversion result sent by the MU with the result obtained on the
MC).

5687Project: VW SIMOS 18.1 EA888 Document key: 10213413 SPE 000 DE
Baseline: SC8L50Y0 Copyright Continental AG

ECM3, ECM3 General
Figure 18.2.1:
Figure 1: Sketch of processor monitoring with two power stages
The monitoring concept described here is generic in the sense that it works regardless of how the MU is
realized in terms of actual hardware (�C vs. ASIC), Hence the primary design is intended to be used on engine
management systems (EMSs) for gasoline/diesel engines and transmission control units (TCUs) the same
mechanisms can be applied for other control units (e.g. Electrical vehicles) as well.
The two system components, MC and MU, mutually monitor each other (just to be clear about the fact that
not only the MU monitors the MC). For instance, assume that there is a failure in the calculations of the ALU
(arithmetic logic unit) of the MC. This could produce potentially dangerous results: e.g., due to a faulty calcula-
tion, the ECU might increase the engine speed too much for the driver to control the car. Additionally, the MC
itself might not be able to detect such a fault and react appropriately (e.g., perform a reset, or switch off the
engine): after all, it cannot even be guaranteed that the processor notices the fault, a (from the external point
of view) faulty processor might ?internally? believe that the system, including itself, is functioning correctly.
All of these mutual monitoring activities are achieved by means of a repeated ? question and answer ? (Q&A)
game: the MU sends questions to the MC, and the MC sends back the respective answers. Based on the
quality of the sent questions and received answers, both components can tell whether the respective other
component is still working correctly.
File: 7E108D01.00A
5688Project: VW SIMOS 18.1 EA888 Document key: 10213413 SPE 000 DE
Baseline: SC8L50Y0 Copyright Continental AG

Copyright �Continental AG. Transmittal, reproduction, dissemination and/or editing of this document as well as utilisation of its contents and communication thereof to others without
expressed authorisation are prohibited. Offenders will be held liable for payment of damages. All rights created by patent grant or registration of a utility model or design patent are reserved.
ECM3, ECM3 General
If there are faults detected while the ECU is running (by whatever means available), appropriate fault reactions
are carried out either by the MC or by the MU, whichever detects the error. In order to be able to transfer the
actuators to a safe state as a fault reaction, there have to be corresponding connections (?switch-off paths?) on
the hardware level between MC/MU and the relevant power stages. Note that, if the MU detects a fault on
the MC, it disables the power stages, and triggers a reset of the MC (the standard fault reaction), this reset is
then fed back from the MC to the MU so that the complete system is restarted (potentially utilizing external
components like, e.g., power supply).
As an immediate consequence of the separation on the hardware level, since each component has its own
parameter memory for variables and is running its own algorithms (in case the MU is realized by an ASIC,
this refers to the circuitry that is hard-wired into the chip), variables on the MU are, a priori, not visible (i.e.
available) on the MC, and vice versa, unless they are speci?cally transferred to the other component via the
communication interface: variables are local to the MU or the MC. Moreover, even after being transmitted
from one component to the other, variables on the MC and the MU will usually have different names since
the communication is based on values, not names (despite ?containing? the same values!), and variable names
re?ect the content of the variables, which can very well be different on MC and MU.
It should furthermore be noted that any value exchanged between MC and MU can always only be asnapshot
of a variable since it can only contain the actual value of the variable at the time of the transmission: consider
the case a variable X is sent from the MU to the MC at a certain time t; if the variable is changed on the
MU at time t+1, this update stays local to the MU in the sense that the MC only notices it if the changed X is
re-transmitted to the MC after the update.
From a functional point of view, the main purpose of the processor monitoring is to monitor the proper func-
tioning of the MC, thereby, continuing the layer-approach of the over-all system design (level 1 contains engine
control functions and their diagnoses, level 2 monitors these functions and diagnoses by re-calculating the
necessary values in an independent way to provide a means of judging their plausibility), in particular and
most importantly, ensuring the proper functioning of the process monitoring. From this approach, the follow-
ing main objectives of processor monitoring are derived:
1. memory checks on MC (both RAM and ROM);
2. memory checks on MU (RAM and ROM); this depends on the hardware realization of the MU; on an
ASIC, a RAM check shall be performed as usual; however, in place of a ROM check, there shall be a built-
in self test (BIST) which tests the proper functioning of certain parts of the circuitry (mostly those parts
responsible for triggering a fault reaction);
3. switch-off path check: after each (re-)initialization of the system, it must be checked whether the switch-
off paths of the system work properly, viz., whether they can actually switch off the safety-relevant power
stages should there be the need to do so later on;
4. program ?ow monitoring (PFM) : it shall be checked that (monitoring-relevant) tasks (of level 2) on the
MC are performed in the correct order and with the correct timing; here, ?task?

refers to a given and
?xed sequence of modules running in the same nominal time grid (i.e., functionally connected parts of
processor monitoring);
5. function-speci?c instruction set test (FS-IST) : it shall be tested whether the processor correctly per-
forms the (monitoring-relevant) calculations needed for the process monitoring on the MC; this shall
be achieved by performing a number of test calculations; in order to avoid any effects of these (addi-
tional) test calculations on the actual monitoring functionality (and in line with VDA requirements), these
test calculations are performed by a copy of some of the (monitoring-relevant) parts of the process
monitoring located in separate memory on the MC which (being a copy of level 2 functionality) is also
known as ?level 2??? (L2?).
Note that PFM and the FS-IST complement each other to achieve a complete monitoring of the processor
functionality as possible: while PFM checks whether the necessary tasks are executed in thecorrect order and
with the correct timing, the FS-IST additionally checks that the requiredcalculations are performed correctly(so
that the tasks can properly execute and calculate the ?right? result - provided the employed algorithm is correct

correctness lies in the hands of the developer and cannot be tested (in this way)!).
Function overview diagram[1]:
[1]The diagram primarily re?ects the functional structure, which is not necessarily equal to the partitioning into
speci?cations (although the two views are closely linked).
Figure 18.2.2:
States of the Components
The behavior of both components of the processor monitoring (i.e., MC and MU) is described by two au-
tonomous state machines, re?ecting the fact that both constitute separate components of a distributed sys-
tem and as such should really have a separate state space.

ECM3, ECM3 General
Even so, the structure of the two state machines is basically identical, mostly because the two components
have a common task, viz., perform the processor monitoring. Nevertheless, as the two parts run independently
of each other, both could be in mismatching states; it is the task of the communication interface to prohibit
such cases by ensuring that the components synchronously progress through their states in the correct or-
der.
In each state of the state machines the MU as well as the MC performs de?ned actions. Some of these checks
are done once (e.g. switch off path check) others run continuously (e.g. Program ?ow monitoring) during one
(re-)initialization phase. The details of the state machine as well as the actions performed within the different
states can be found in the according section of the speci?cation.
Communication between MC and MU
In order to set up the aforementioned Q&A game, the two components need to exchange data: Since the
detection of errors is based on the data received the communication needs to be designed in a robust way
that each receiver is able to detect a corruption in the communication.
This communication interface can be implemented e.g. in the form of the S erial Peripheral Interface (SPI). In
this way, MC and MU are able to synchronize their progress and, in doing so, they can mutually monitor the
performed actions.
Details concerning the communication, the protocols and the algorithms can be found in the according sec-
tion of the speci?cation.
Table of error codes of MC and MU
The error codes of detected malfunctions are stored on the MU and MC independently.
Since there are errors which can be detected only by one of the two algorithms the error codes on the MU do
not necessary match with the error codes on the MC and vice versa.
A detailed description of the error codes can be found in the according section of the speci?cation.

� General Information
This module contains several functions related to the fault reaction of processor monitoring on the MC.
1) Central fault reaction of processor monitoring on the MC. This action performs the central fault reaction
from Level 3 on Main controller. This action does the restart of ASW when ever there is error raised and stores
the information in the counter CTR_RST_MC how many times Restart is carried out. If the Restart is carried
out more than 7 times and on 8th Restart it will request for Disabling of Power stages. Since this function
is not activated with a ?xed recurrence but only called when an error has actually occurred, the complete
functionality is encapsulated in the action ACTION_ECM3_McFaultReaction() which can be imported and called
by other functions, should they require to trigger an immediate fault reaction
2) Healing of Reset counter CTR_RST_MC and Error information(ERR_COD_MC)
3) Requesting for Disabling of Power stages
4) Anti bounce technique for Error raised
5) Redundant Switch of Path
This speci?cation has to be coded according to the following method description:
"M730204: Coding rules for process monitoring SW ECM2."
18.5.1 Healing of Reset counter ( CTR_RST_MC ) and Error Information(ERR_COD_MC)
� General Information
If the MC is in NORMAL state (which indicates that there is no error present) for a certain time (4s), then the
reset counter is decreased by 1 since the system has been stable long enough to assume that there is currently
no problem present; if this decreasing results in a reset counter of 0, also the error code and the error indication
shall be cleared
This function shall be incorporated in ecm3_dtsysfarea__HealCtrRst().
The primary initialization needed before using fault reaction shall be incorporated inecm3_dtsysfarea__preini().
The initialization shall be incorporated in ecm3_dtsysfarea__rst().

18.5.2 Temporarily Disable of Power Stages
� General Information
MC shall temporarily disable the power stages by setting LV_ERR_TMP_MU_MC = 1, plus additionally calling
ACTION_ECM3_PwsLock() (in order to ensure that process monitoring also disables the power stages);
MC shall enable the power stages by setting LV_ERR_TMP_MU_MC = 0 and LV_ERR_MU_MC = 0 (cf. remark
above!), plus additionally calling the action ACTION_ECM3_PwsUnlock().
In INI_NOT_READY, INIT and CONF the MC shall temporarily disable the power stages.
The MC shall temporarily disable the power stages in NORM:
- if the reset counters of both MC and MU is greater 1
- during L2 ROM check not ?nished
- during SOPC is active
- if MU indicates that NDIS1 is disabled
Take care of Disable OS task switching to avoid inconsistency.
This function shall be incorporated in ecm3_dtsysfarea__TempDisable().
The initialization shall be incorporated in ecm3_dtsysfarea__rst().

18.5.5 ACTION_ECM3_McFaultReaction
This action performs the central fault reaction From Level 3 on Main controller. This action does the restart
of ASW when ever there is error raised and stores the information in the counter CTR_RST_MC how many
times Restart is carried out. If the Restart is carried out more than 7 times and on 8th Restart it will request for
Disabling of Power stages.
IN <PRM_ERR_COD_MC> Error code of an ECM3 Fault detected on MC
18.5.6 ACTION_ECM3_RedSwitchOffPath
In case process or processor monitoring on the MC detect a fatal error and attempt to disable the safety-
relevant power stages, they can also use the switch-off paths on the monitoring unit to redundantly perform
the switching-off. This is done via an action call (from within process monitoring) which sets a ?ag in the
processor monitoring that forces the MC to deliberately send wrong FS-IST answers to the MU which in turn,
potentially after some debouncing, leads to a fault reaction on the MU and in particular to disabling the safety-
relevant power stages (hence the name ?redundant switch-off path? as the MU is eventually prompted to also
disable the power stages).
There shall be an interface between process and processor monitoring which, when used, causes the proces-
sor monitoring on the MC to permanently send wrong FS-IST answers to the MU, in this way eventually (after
debouncing) resulting in a fault reaction of the MU.
This interface shall be realised by providing the action call ACTION_ECM3_RedSwitchOffPath() to process mon-
itoring which shall set the ?ag LV_MC_DR_OFF;
LV_MC_DR_OFF shall be stored as together with its complement LV_MC_DR_OFF_CPL and shall only be ac-
cessed via the RAM check service action ACTION_ECM3_WriteChkCpl(); its default value in case of a RAM
error shall be 1, indicating that the redundant switch-off path has been triggered.
It has to be ensured that a complement check for LV_MC_DR_OFF is performed at every activation of the
module, regardless of any updates of the variable.

� General Information
This module describes all functions related to monitoring of communications on the MC.
This module provides a data interface from/to the other modules (output data/input data).
In this module only data / info transmission is done (related to module data interface), but no functional deci-
sions based on those data.
The complete function is split in two parts. First where communication data from Monitoring Unit are read
and a second where communication data from MC are send to MU and the communication is triggered.
This speci?cation has to be coded according to the following method description:
"M730204: Coding rules for process monitoring SW ECM2."
18.6.1 ecm3_dtsyscom__ReadMuData
� General Information
Main input to this function are the received MU infos using the infrastructure Interfaces ACTION_INFR_ECM3Get*.
This module detects the state of MU (STATE_MU) and extracts other received information.
This module extracts the received MU state after ?rst communication. The received information depends on
the current state of the communication (transmitted command).
The result of Readiness-check is stored in STATE_MU.
In case, that an error frame is detected, the output information is not updated, it stays unchanged.
In case, that the header information is corrupted or any invalid numerical value a fault reaction is triggered
otherwise header information is numerically valid. STATE_MU is updated.
A parity and complement check is performed in this function. It is compared whether value und complement
of received data in INIT2, CONF1, CONF2 matches and parity of MU con?guration (NORM1)and PFM con?gu-
ration (NORM2) match each other. In case of differences, fault reaction is called.
This function checks in NORM2, whether the received IGK is correct.
In case it is correct: Update IGK, otherwise trigger a fault reaction.
The initializations shall be incorporated in ecm3_dtsyscom__rst().

� General Information
The switch-off path check (SOPC, or "Predrive Check") checks whether the system?s switch-off paths, i.e., dedi-
cated physical connections with the purpose to disable the safety-relevant power stages, work correctly should
the need arise to use them. Both MC and MU can have more such switch-off paths.
The check itself is performed during the system?s start-up. The idea is that to attempt to disable the power
stages via MC or MU and then, having obtained status information from the power stages, to judge whether
they are indeed disabled. The status of the power stages during the SOPC shall be collected on the MC, the
MU cannot read back status information.
This speci?cation has to be coded according to the following method description:
"M730204: Coding rules for process monitoring SW ECM2."
18.7.1 ecm3_dtsyssopc__1()
� General Information
The status information of a power stage shall be retrieved using the action ACTION_INFR_ECM3GetDiagPws(),
the requirements to these actions are described in the section "ECM3 - MC requirements to infrastructure
interface."
If any of the two actions returns "unde?ned" as status information from a power stage, it shall be assumed that
the corresponding switch-off path is not working;
The result of the SOPC for the disable paths shall be stored beginning with LSB bits in the 16-bit vector LF_
ECM3_SOPC_RESP, which shall be stored together with its complement, using the RAM check service actions;
its default value being 0 (= no switch-off path working); it shall be ensured that a complement check is per-
formed at each activation of the module, regardless of any updates of the variable; A set bit shall indicate that
the switch-off path is working.
The central fault reaction of processor monitoring shall be triggered in case the status of the switch-off paths
would not permit reaching the safe state of the system.

ECM3, Program ?ow monitoring
Program ?ow monitoring (PFM) is one of the ways in which the processor monitoring functionality monitors
whether the MC-SW, most importantly the process monitoring, is still executed ?properly.?
From the perspective of PFM, ?properly? means that the safety-relevant functions of process monitoring are
executed with the
correct recurrence and in the correct sequence.
The basic algorithm of PFM works as follows.
The MU sends a bit pattern, the so-called PFM synchronisation nibble, to the MC: this
synchronisation nibble contains one bit for each of 4 PFM tasks (numbered from 0 to 3) to be monitored. Here,
?PFM task? denotes a collection of software modules (=functions), in particular of process monitoring, which
have to be executed in a de?ned order and which have to be executed in the same time grid. There can be
up to 126 "inspection points" in each of the monitored tasks.
Having been received by the MC, the synchronisation nibble is used to obtain the so-called PFM response byte:
if the monitored modules (of process monitoring or others) from one task are executed and, furthermore, if
they are executed in the correct order (note that these are two different constraints!), they manipulate the bit
in the response byte corresponding to ?their? task in such a way that it is ?nally toggled. The (thus potentially
updated) response byte is sent back to the MU. In how far the sent response byte (MC ->MU) differs from the
originally transmitted synchronisation nibble (MU- >MC) depends solely on which monitored modules were
executed until the communication where the response byte was transmitted.
It should be noted that the MU sends two kinds of information: synchronisation nibble and PFM Anti-bounce
counter and status (a set bit indicates that the corresponding counter has value >0) on the MU.
Since the way the MU manipulates the synchronisation nibble is the reference for how the MC should do the
same task, a mismatch between the synchronisation nibble and the PFM response of the MC indicates that
the program execution on the MC is not performed in the prescribed way; as a consequence, a debounced
fault reaction will be performed, using separate anti-bounce counters for each of the 4 tasks.
This speci?cation has to be coded according to the following method description:
"M730204: Coding rules for process monitoring SW ECM2."
This section describes the value assignment for the generic PFM con?guration data of Processor Monitoring
18.8.1 Monitoring of timely updates of PFM information sent by MU
� General Information
This function ecm3_dtsyspfm__1_norm describes the mechanism by which the MC monitors whether the MU
sends, in the corresponding intervals of time, the toggled synchronization byte.
In this way it is possible to detect whether the MU is still running.
The initialization shall be incorporated in ecm3_dtsyspfm__rst().
� Application Conditions

� Signal ?ow diagram:
Figure 18.8.1:
Description of Signal ?ow diagram for Program Flow Monitoring:
The MU PFM mechanism is based on internal MU timers. The time depends on the considered PFM bit and
also the used con?guration.
The internal PFM synchronization nibble is after initialization 0x00. Hence, the ?rst expected valid answer is ?1?
within the con?gured time.
If this answer is received, the anti bounce counter on MU is decremented, the timer is restarted and the internal
PFM bit for the task is toggled.
SPI0: INIT frames, no PFM contribution
SPI1: Frame1 ? ?rst normal, transition to NORMAL - ->start PFM_x_TMR

ECM3, Program ?ow monitoring
Frame2 ? ?rst PFM answer frame, PFM check shows no new PFM information
- ->no action, since timer not elapsed
SPI2: Frame2 ? PFM answer frame, PFM check shows no new PFM information
- ->no action, since timer not elapsed
SPI3: Frame2 - PFM answer frame, PFM check shows correct answer within speci?ed time (i.e. toggled bit for
PFM_0)
- ->restart PFM_0_TMR, copy PFM_0_MC to PFM_0_MU, PFM_0_ABC decrement
SPI4: Frame2 ? PFM answer frame, PFM check shows correct answer (i.e. toggled bit for PFM_0)
- ->restart PFM_0_TMR, copy PFM_0_MC to PFM_0_MU, PFM_0_ABC decrement
SPI5: Frame2 ? PFM answer frame, PFM check shows no new PFM information
- ->no action, since timer not elapsed
TIME6: PFM0 timer has elapsed - ->PFM_0_ABC increment, restart timer PFM_0_TMR
(remark: in case PFM_0_ABC>=PFM_0_ABC_MAX trigger central fault reaction for PFM_0)
SPI7: Frame2 ? PFM answer frame, PFM check shows correct answer (i.e. toggled bit for PFM_0)
- ->restart PFM_0_TMR, copy PFM_0_MC to PFM_0_MU, PFM_0_ABC decrement
In order to check whether this toggling process on the MU still works correctly the
actual received PFM synchronization nibble has to be equal to last sent PFM answer.
During wrong response test the toggle monitoring is not activ.

� Function Description
In order to check if the program ?ow monitoring mechanism on MU is able to detect a wrong program ?ow
on MC there will be deliberately wrong answers sent to MU.
This check will be done cyclically without risk an unwanted reset and fault reaction by MU, i.e. as soon as the
MU gives an anti bounce counter status of 0 for a dedicated PFM task the sending of wrong answers will be
activated. The MU reaction can be expected earliest after the timer on MU has elapsed. Therefore, test cycle
counters have been introduced allowing to consider ECM3 recurrence rate and con?guration of all PFM timers
on MU.
If a correct working MU shows the expected behavior the sending of deliberately wrong answers will be
stopped, the anti bounce counter on MU will heal.
If MU does not show the expected behavior within the speci?ed time, an anti bounce counter on MC will be
incremented and ?nally a fault reaction initiated by ECM3 will occur.

18.8.4 ACTION_ECM3_ServiceTaskPfm
Check if the current value of the control byte is equal to the j-th entry of the control byte con?guration.
If the check is successful, the control byte will be set to the j-th + 1 entry of the control byte con?guration,
otherwise the control byte shall be set to the default error value.
18.8.5 ACTION_ECM3_ServicePfm
Check if the PFM status byte for task K has reached the de?ned end value.
If this is the case, the position K the received synchronization nibble from MU shall be inverted and copied to
position K of the answer, otherwise the position K shall be copied without inverting.
Additionally, the PFM status byte for task K has to be set to the initial value.

ECM3, Function speci?c instruction set test

� General Information
The function-speci?c instruction set test (FS-IST) complements the program ?ow monitoring (PFM) function-
ality in an effort to obtain as complete a monitoring of the proper functioning of the main controller (MC) as
possible. The goal of the FS-IST is to check whether the MC is capable of correctly performing the calculations
necessary for the most important safety-relevant functions in the process monitoring ("VDA level 2") - hence
the name function-speci?c instruction-set test: only computations with relevance for the monitoring concept
(the ?function? under consideration) are tested, as opposed to a complete instruction-set test.
As already stated, the FS-IST checks whether certain safety-relevant calculations are performed correctly.
These so-called test calculations are performed by a copy of the relevant modules of process monitoring
(so as not to ?disturb? the action process monitoring by the test calculations); these copied level 2 modules
constitute the so-called copy of process monitoring, or level 2?. Although conceptually part of processor moni-
toring, the level 2? are in practise more closely associated to process monitoring than to processor monitoring:
each change of a process monitoring module a copy of which is part of level 2? has to be carried out also for
the corresponding level 2? module.
Since the test calculations are also performed on the MC, i.e., by the same processor that performs the actual
(level 2) calculations, the monitoring unit (MU) is used to initiate the FS-IST and check whether the calculations
arrive at the correct results (otherwise no reasonable way of detecting faults is possible).
Concretely, the FS-IST is performed in the following way (there are some points to note about the timing which
will be explained after the description of the basic algorithm):
? on the MU, there exists an array of test indices, or questions; these questions are
simply bit patterns which are cyclically sent to the MC, i.e., at the beginning, the
?rst entry of the array is sent, then the second, and so on (in the error-free case,
the case of errors will be described later); for these question, there are
corresponding answers, or responses, which are also stored in an array on the MU
? these test indices, once they have been received by the MC-part of processor
monitoring, are then sent to the level 2? via an interface which, depending on
the question from the MU, determines the starting values (i.e., values of inputs, etc.)
for the level 2? modules;
? using this chosen starting values, level 2? calculates according to the modules,
depending on the ability of the processor, yielding a speci?c actual output value
that is then forwarded to the MC-part of processor monitoring, again via the interface,
together with the expected result for this particular test index;
? the MC-part of processor monitoring then determines (by comparing the actual with
the expected output value) whether the test calculation was performer successfully
before sending a response, or answer, back to the MU; note that this answer is also
in?uenced by other factors (e.g., if a fault by the MC-side of processor monitoring
was detected, this answer is forced to be false from the expected answer on the MU)

ECM3, Function speci?c instruction set test
? the MU receives the answer of the MC-part of processor monitoring and compares
that to the entry in its array of expected results at the position corresponding to
the sent test index;
? if this comparison has a positive result, and anti-bounce counter shall be decreased
(without creating an under?ow, i.e., if its value is already 0 nothing shall happen)
and the procedure shall continue as described before;
? if the comparison shows that a wrong answer has been received, an anti-bounce
counter shall be increased; upon reaching its maximal value, the central fault reaction
shall be triggered; if the maximal value is not reached
when increasing the anti-bounce counter, the particular question that was wrongly
answered shall be re-sent to the MC for as long as the anti-bounce has not reached 0,
This speci?cation has to be coded according to the following method description:
"M730204: Coding rules for process monitoring SW ECM2."

Recurrence: Refer to ECM3 Synchronisation Constraints Specification(108E)
� Function Description
The question index for the function speci?c instruction set test sent by monitoring unit has to be monitored.
In MU a pseudo random algorithm is implemented which sends the different questions in arbitrary order. The
only limitation of these algorithm ensures, that in each question cycle every question is sent exactly once
(assuming all questions are answer correctly and no wrong response test is active).
Following assumptions shall hold to allow a simple implementation of the monitoring of the sent question
index.
Basic idea is to de?ne a bit ?eld of length of number of questions (either 16 or 32, depending on MU con?gu-
ration).
Every time a question index is received the corresponding position of the bit ?eld is increased to 1.
If all question indices are transmitted, the bit ?eld has to be initialized again.
As soon as one question index is not received between a de?ned time window an error is present.

Description:
The error history records which component has triggered the update of error memory information:
1) Update MC error information in PRE_INI.
2) Update MU error information after a successful INI_NOT_READY communication plus
request to update ERRM memory.
3) Disable state update MU and MC error information plus request to update ERRM memory.
The history stores the current value of reset counter, error code, additional Information, and component (MC
or MU), and the corresponding old values are stored where index Zero of the below mentioned variables
represents current cycle error and Index 1
represents previously calculated error and Index 2 so on....
ECM3_ERR_MEM_STATE[0] Represents Error from MC or MU
ECM3_ERR_MEM_ERR_COD[0] Error code from MC or MU
ECM3_ERR_MEM_CTR_RST[0] Reset counter from MC or MU
ECM3_ERR_MEM_ADD_INFO[0] Additional information stored when there is MC or MU error
After the history is potentially updated, the project-speci?c function ACTION_ECM3_McErrmService(), which is
imported from the application incidences is called and this data is exported to ERRM.
This speci?cation has to be coded according to the following method description:
"M730204: Coding rules for process monitoring SW ECM2."

18.10.2 Request to update of ECM3 error memory information in ERRM
� General Information
This sub-function describes when the error history for internal ECM3 and ERRM memory gets updated with
new error.
They are:
1) Update MC error information in PRE_INI.
2) Update MU error information after a successful INI_NOT_READY communication plus request
to update ERRM memory.
3) Disable state update MU and MC error information plus request to update ERRM memory.
This function shall be incorporated in ecm3_dtsysemm_Update().

18.11.1 Project-speci?c con?guration - Error memory service function
� General Information
The function incorporates the following requirements:
The action ACTION_ECM3_McErrmService() shall be called when all the necessary information is available.
When the action is called, it is ?rst tested whether an update of the error history was performed right before
the action was called. For every fault, environmental conditions are stored in the environmental data variables
ENVD_x_MON_3; the stored content is chosen to help analysing the fault scenario afterwards; more information
can be found in the formula section below.
Design speci?ed on ERRM 8xx and greater.
Diag must be de?ned accordingly in table of failure depending on ERRM version implemented on the project

In order to prevent a start of Processor Monitoring SW while the "environmental condition" inside the ECU are
not yet in a de?ned state, the transition from PREINI to IINI_NOT_READY can only be performed under speci?c

18.11.4 Project-speci?c con?guration - Extension of power-latch phase for Standard ROM
check
� General Information
Since the Standard ROM check is calculated in the background, it is not pre-determined how long it will take to
complete; however, there is the requirement that the ROM check has to be completed at least once per driving
cycle. Consequently, in order to ful?l the mentioned requirement, the power latch phase (the phase after the
ignition has been switched off, KL15 = 0, but before the ECU is switched off) shall be extended variably for (at
least) as long the duration of one complete checksum calculation.

� General Information
This module describes different memory checks on the MC:
- ECM3 response on Level 1 RAM check;
- ECM3 response on Level 1 ROM check;
- ECM3 services for Level 2 RAM check;
- Level2 cyclic ROM check performed by ECM3.
On the MC, there are two different ROM checks:
? the standard ROM check which checks the whole ROM (code, constants, calibration data with the ex-
ception of areas which can be changed during runtime like FLASH or EEPROM);
? the cyclic ROM check for process monitoring which checks the ROM of process monitoring (consisting
of the code, constants, and calibration data of process monitoring, plus the code of all library functions
called in the code of process monitoring).
The difference between the two ROM checks is the fact that the standard ROM check is performed onlyonce
after power-up (after reset only if the reset occurred before its successful completion) while the ROM check for
process monitoring is cyclic, i.e., it is re-started after completion.
Several RAM checks have to be performed on the MC to test the integrity of the RAM:
? there shall be a non-destructive RAM check for those data that have to be stored in a reset-safe way, and
those RAM areas that are shared between BOOT and ECU software;
? for all remaining RAM areas, there shall be a destructive RAM check which also performs an initialisation
to 0;
? additionally, there shall be a cyclic RAM check for the level 2 RAM areas and for some of the RAM areas
of the processor monitoring: this is done by storing those variables as pair of value and complement
and performing consistency checks when accessing the variables;
? in order to prevent faults due to interrupt handling while level 2 is active, also a stack check is imple-
mented which checks the relevant memory area on the stack where the level 2 register content will be
stored in case of an interrupt.
The ?rst two kinds of RAM checks have to be performed in such a way as to be able to detect static errors
like stuck bits/cells. The last two kinds of RAM check are used to detect dynamic errors like a bit toggling
during runtime or one (process/processor monitoring) module corrupting the memory area of another one,
or problems with the stack memory.

18.12.2 ROM checks of processor monitoring: Cyclic ROM check for process monitor-
ing
� General Information
The cyclic ROM check for process monitoring ("level 2 ROM check") checks all level 2 ROM and level 3 ROM
areas, which are different from the level 1 ROM areas, as well as the corresponding constant and calibration
data, very much like the standard ROM check for the level 1 ROM areas.
Following
However, there are two differences between the two ROM checks.
First of all, while the level 1 ROM check is only executed once per driving cycle, the level 2 ROM check is
performed cyclically, i.e., once it is ?nished, it starts again.
Secondly, the level 2 ROM check also takes into account all library functions (e.g., from the mathematics library)
which might potentially called from within any level 2 or level 3 function.
This can be achieved, e.g., by performing acomplete check of those external libraries or by the use of so-called
inline functions where only the code of those functions which are actually called is tested: the code of inline
functions is directly copied to the place where the function is called, instead of performing a function call;
concretely, the code of an inline function from the mathematics library called from a
level 2/level 3 function thus becomes part of the level 2/level 3 code and is consequently tested by the level 2
code ROM check.
Note that the two mentioned ways to check external library functions were just chosen as examples: there
might very well be other ways to include such libraries in the level 2 ROM check, it just has to be ensured
that each function called inside a level 2/level 3 function is included in the level 2 ROM check (one way or
another).
This function shall be incorporated in function call ecm3_dtsysmmon__RomChkLvl2().
The initialization shall be incorporated in ecm3_dtsysmmon__rst().

� General Information

ECM3, Memory monitoring
This special RAM check works by storing a "critical" variable as value and complement. In order to avoid
masking any errors, the storage shall be done in an uncached manner directly into the RAM (for both read-
and write-accesses).
Description:
The function, via the exported actions, incorporates the following requirements:
RAM check service actions of processor monitoring on MC
All variables of the process monitoring which are located in the RAM and used in the next recurrence of a task
(e.g. anti-bounce-counters) or in a different successive task are stored as pairs consisting of the value and its
complement.
After execution of a level 2 module, its results have to be copied from registers into variables located in the
RAM. After storing a value from an internal register in the RAM, together with its complement in a variable of
the name var_CPL if the original variable was named var (example: LV_OFF_IV_MON_CPL contains the com-
plement of LV_OFF_IV_MON), the value is read back from the RAM and compared with the original value of the
register. This procedure is performed by the action ACTION_ECM3_WriteChkCpl() described below.
At the beginning of the following recurrence of the task, the two complementary variables are checked for
plausibility. Also intermediate results, which cannot be completely handled by the internal registers, are stored
in value-complement pairs and checked for plausibility. This is done at the beginning of a level 2 module
using the action ACTION_ECM3_ChkCpl() or ACTION_ECM3_ReadChkCpl(); the difference between these two
actions is that the action ACTION_ECM3_ChkCpl() only performs a plausibility check for a variable and its
complement variable without loading the actual value into a register, while ACTION_ECM3_ReadChkCpl() also
loads a register with the value of the given variable.
If a RAM fault is detected by these functions, an immediate fault reaction shall be performed via ACTION_
ECM3_L2RamFaultReaction().
All RAM check service actions have to be implemented in such a way that they are universally usable, in
particular regardless of the type of their parameters.
� Application Conditions
Initialisation: Before the first test of the complementary variables, all appropriate
variables must be initialized properly using the action ACTION_
ECM3_WriteChkCpl().
Recurrence: All the actions in this function are called.
18.12.6 RAM checks of processor monitoring: Stack check service action of processor
monitoring
� General Information
In addition to the RAM checks described above (the start-up checks described in G6 and the cyclic level 2
RAM check described in G7), there is another memory test to ensure the integrity of memory areas used by
the stack. The motivation for the function is as follows.
While a process monitoring (level 2) module is executed, an interrupt might occur. Prompted by the interrupt,
the current content of the registers, plus "logistic" data like a return address, are stored on the stack. Once the

ECM3, Memory monitoring
interrupt handling is ?nished, the register content is restored from the stack and program execution continues
where it left off before the interrupt (the address is also determined from the data saved on the stack).
However, if the used stack memory is corrupted, the level 2 register content might be corrupted without being
detected; this could either lead to a dormant fault (level 2 might not catch an existing error) or reduce the
availability of the vehicle (a level 2 fault reaction might get triggered unnecessarily).
Finally, if the return address is corrupted by being stored on the stack, the level 2 module might not be com-
pleted (leading to a problem with program ?ow monitoring (PFM), again reducing availability), or some code
passages of the level 2 module might be omitted (again leading to a dormant fault).
Consequently, at the beginning of each level 2 module, the relevant stack areas have to be checked so that
in case of an interrupt during the execution of the module, the necessary data can be correctly stored and
recovered.
Description:
The function incorporates the following requirements:
Stack check service action of processor monitoring on MC
The interface to level 2 shall be provided via the exported action ACTION_ECM3_McChkStack().
Remark:
? the action shall be called at the very beginning of each level 2 module in order to ensure that the relevant
stack area is OK in case the level 2 module is interrupted;
? the action shall be "sandwiched" in between two PFM actions in order to ensure that the stack check
action is entered and left properly since its code might not be completely ROM-checked.
When ACTION_ECM3_McChkStack() is called, the infrastructure action ACTION_INFR_ECM3StackCheckOk()
shall be called in order to perform the stack check; the requirements to this action shall be described in the
IRS of Processor Monitoring.
ACTION_INFR_ECM3StackCheckOk() shall return a ?ag indicating whether the stack check was successful or
not.
If ACTION_INFR_ECM3StackCheckOk() indicates that the stack check was unsuccessful, an immediate fault
reaction shall be performed via ACTION_ECM3_HandleAbc(1,L2_RAM).
The call and the execution of ACTION_ECM3_McChkStack() shall use no stack.
� Application Conditions
Recurrence: The function is called via ACTION_ECM3_McChkStack().

This diagram is a functional block diagram, representing the architecture and interconnections of a processor monitoring system, which could be implemented using tools like Simulink for modeling and simulation, or directly in software/hardware. It is not a literal Simulink screenshot with specific block icons, but it describes a system suitable for such a representation.

## Function
The primary function of this diagram is to illustrate a distributed "Processor Monitoring 'ECM3' - Level 3" system designed for high integrity and fault tolerance in an automotive Electronic Control Module (ECM) context. It depicts how a Master Controller (MC) and a Monitoring Unit (MU) independently and mutually supervise each other and their internal components to detect faults and trigger appropriate reactions. The goal is to ensure the reliable and safe operation of the system by continuously verifying the health of processors, memories, and communication paths.

## Inputs
*   **ADC (Analog-to-Digital Converter):** Feeds into both the MC and MU, implying both units process or monitor raw analog sensor data.
*   **Level 1:** An input to the MC, likely representing a higher-level system state, mode, or control input.
*   **ECM2:** Another input to the MC, suggesting data or commands from a distinct Electronic Control Module or subsystem.
*   **Internal States/Data:** Implicitly, the various monitoring blocks (e.g., PFM, FS-IST, Cyclical RAM/ROM checks, Self-test) require access to the internal program execution flow, memory contents, processor registers, and operational states of the MC and MU as their inputs for analysis.
*   **Communication MC <-> MU:** Bidirectional communication data and status signals exchanged between the MC and MU serve as input for their respective "Communication Monitoring" blocks.

## Outputs
*   **Fault reaction on MC:** An output from the MC's monitoring logic, signaling that a fault has been detected within the MC's domain, requiring a specific fault handling or safety reaction.
*   **Switch-off Path Check:** An output from the MC, indicating the status or verification result of a critical safety switch-off mechanism.
*   **Fault reaction on MU:** An output from the MU's monitoring logic, indicating a fault has been detected within the MU's domain, requiring a specific fault handling or safety reaction.
*   **Communication MC <-> MU:** While also an input for monitoring, the data and status signals generated and sent by each unit to the other constitute an output, conveying their health and operational status.
*   **Implicit Status/Diagnostics:** The various checks effectively produce internal status signals that determine the overall health and lead to the explicit "Fault reaction" outputs.

## Logic Flow

The system's logic flow is distributed across two primary components: the Master Controller (MC) and the Monitoring Unit (MU), with critical inter-communication.

**1. Master Controller (MC) Monitoring Path:**
    *   **External Inputs:** ADC, Level 1, and ECM2 signals are provided to the MC.
    *   **Memory Integrity Checks:**
        *   **Std. ROM-Check (Standard Read-Only Memory Check):** Verifies the integrity of the MC's program memory.
        *   **Std. RAM-Check (Standard Random Access Memory Check):** Verifies the integrity of the MC's working memory.
        *   These standard checks feed into the main MC Processor Monitoring block.
    *   **Processor Monitoring 'ECM3' - Level 3 on MC:** This block encapsulates several advanced monitoring functions:
        *   **Redundant switch off path:** Checks the integrity and functionality of a backup or redundant safety shutdown path.
        *   **FS-IST (Functional Safety - In-Service Test):** Executes specific tests during normal operation to ensure that safety-critical functionalities of the MC are still working correctly.
        *   **PFM (Program Flow Monitoring):** Monitors the execution sequence of the MC's software to detect anomalies like infinite loops, unexpected jumps, or crashes.
        *   **Compatibility Check:** Verifies data consistency, timing, or operational compatibility between different internal MC modules or external interfaces.
        *   **Cyclical RAM check Level 2 / Cyclical ROM check Level 2:** Performs more extensive or continuous memory checks than the standard ones, potentially at a higher diagnostic level or frequency.
        *   **Switch-off Path Check:** Provides an output reflecting the status of the switch-off path verification.
        *   **Fault reaction on MC:** If any of the above checks (including memory checks) detect a fault, this output is activated to initiate a system response.
    *   **Communication Monitoring (MC):** This block specifically monitors the health and integrity of the communication link to the MU.

**2.

*   **Switch-off Path Check:** Provides an output reflecting the status of the switch-off path verification.
        *   **Fault reaction on MC:** If any of the above checks (including memory checks) detect a fault, this output is activated to initiate a system response.
    *   **Communication Monitoring (MC):** This block specifically monitors the health and integrity of the communication link to the MU.

**2. Monitoring Unit (MU) Monitoring Path:**
    *   **External Input:** ADC signal is provided to the MU.
    *   **Level 3 on MU:** This block encapsulates the MU's monitoring functions:
        *   **Compatibility Check:** Similar to the MC, verifies data consistency or operational compatibility within the MU or with relevant interfaces.
        *   **Self-test (ASIC!):** Executes self-diagnostic routines, possibly for an Application-Specific Integrated Circuit (ASIC) or other dedicated hardware within the MU.
        *   **PFM (Program Flow Monitoring):** Monitors the program execution flow of the MU.
        *   **FS-IST (Functional Safety - In-Service Test):** Performs functional safety tests for the MU.
        *   **Fault reaction on MU:** If any of these checks detect a fault, this output is activated to initiate a system response.
    *   **Communication Monitoring (MU):** This block monitors the health and integrity of the communication link to the MC.

**3. Inter-Unit Communication and Cross-Monitoring:**
    *   **Communication MC <-> MU:** A central bidirectional communication link exists between the MC and MU. This link is crucial for exchanging health status, test results, and synchronization signals.
    *   **Mutual Supervision:** Both the MC's and MU's "Communication Monitoring" blocks actively monitor this link. This means each unit is supervising the other's ability to communicate reliably. If one unit fails to send expected messages, sends erroneous messages, or if the communication link itself is compromised, the respective "Communication Monitoring" block will likely flag a fault, contributing to the overall "Fault reaction" of that unit.

**Overall Flow:** The MC and MU operate in parallel, independently executing various self-checks (memory, program flow, functional safety, hardware integrity). Simultaneously, they engage in active communication and monitor the integrity of this communication. A failure in any of these internal checks or in the communication link will trigger a specific "Fault reaction" from the detecting unit, contributing to the system's ability to enter a safe state upon anomaly detection. This architecture provides redundancy and diversity for enhanced safety and reliability.
